La circulation de lâ€™or subsaharien vers les rives de la MÃ©diterranÃ©e a fait lâ€™objet dâ€™une attention particuliÃ¨re de la part des historiens mÃ©diÃ©vistes. Les sources Ã©crites, notamment les textes des gÃ©ographes arabes, tÃ©moignent de la richesse de rÃ©gions dâ€™oÃ¹ proviendrait lâ€™or utilisÃ© pour les monnayages arabo-musulmans. Lâ€™ampleur de cette utilisation demeure nÃ©anmoins difficilement estimable. De la mÃªme maniÃ¨re, si lâ€™exploitation de mines dâ€™argent est documentÃ©e pour le Maghreb, lâ€™utilisation de cette production dans les monnayages de lâ€™Occident musulman nâ€™a que peu Ã©tÃ© mesurÃ©e. Alors que la circulation des mÃ©taux prÃ©cieux en direction dâ€™al-Andalus a essentiellement Ã©tÃ© Ã©tudiÃ©e Ã  partir de tÃ©moignages relatifs Ã  lâ€™or, il semble indispensable dâ€™y associer lâ€™argent afin de comprendre les dynamiques de circulation des mÃ©taux prÃ©cieux dans le bassin occidental de la MÃ©diterranÃ©e. Le projet ALMACIR propose lâ€™Ã©tablissement dâ€™un rÃ©fÃ©rentiel de composition des alliages monÃ©taires Ã  base dâ€™or et dâ€™argent de lâ€™Occident musulman mÃ©diÃ©val grÃ¢ce Ã  des analyses spectromÃ©triques de masse Ã  plasma par couplage inductif par ablation laser (LA-ICP-MS). AprÃ¨s le catalogage et la mise en base de donnÃ©es des plus de 700 dinars et dirhams soumis aux analyses, les rÃ©sultats mettront en avant les teneurs en Ã©lÃ©ments traces, prÃ©sents sous la forme dâ€™impuretÃ©s dans les minerais et susceptibles dâ€™indiquer lâ€™origine des mÃ©taux. Les objectifs seront dâ€™Ã©valuer la circulation de lâ€™or et de lâ€™argent et dâ€™estimer les variations de flux selon les pouvoirs Ã©metteurs, entre les conquÃªtes arabo-musulmanes en Occident au tournant des VIIe-VIIIe siÃ¨cles et la chute de la dynastie almohade en 1269. title: PrÃ©sentation

content:
What were the circulation networks for precious metals used in coinage in the Islamic West, from the Arab conquests to the Berber dynasties (8th-13th centuries)? Where did the gold and silver minted by the various States of the Islamic West come from? To what extent did political changes in the Maghreb and al-Andalus influence the circulation of precious metals?
The ALMACIR project focuses on the western part of the DÄr al-IslÄm, between the Arab conquests of the MaÄ¡rib al-AqsÄ and al-Andalus at the turn of the 7th-8th centuries and the fall of the Almohads in 668/1269. Based on the testimony of written sources, traditional and recent historiography has demonstrated the importance of sub-Saharan gold, the routes of its circulation transiting through SiÇ§ilmÄsa, and the wealth of other Saharan cities at the crossroads of the salt and gold routes, such as AwdaÄ¡ust (in today’s Mauritania). Written sources also shed light on the exploitation of precious metals in the Maghreb. More recently, archaeological studies in North Africa, particularly in SiÇ§ilmÄsa area have added a new dimension to these studies. While the circulation of precious metals has tended to focus on gold, the circulation of silver has to be highlighted, especially its possible movement to the Iberian Peninsula from North Africa, where there were renowned mines, such as those in the Moroccan Atlas whose wealth was highlighted by the 9th century geographer Ibn á¸ªudÄá¸bih. The area was subject to different authorities, with the MaÄ¡rib al-AqsÄ gradually linked to al-Andalus, with the expansion of the Umayyad Caliphate of CÃ³rdoba to the south of the Strait of Gibraltar, until the control of SiÇ§ilmÄsa (366/976), and with the conquests and retreat of the Almoravids and then the Almohads in the 12th and 13th centuries. The project is based on an examination of the circulation of gold and silver in these varying political contexts, through a new light: that of the chemical composition characteristics of coins.
Main objectives:
to assess the circulation of these metals over a broad chronology between sub-Saharan Africa, the MaÄ¡rib al-AqsÄ and al-Andalus; to quantify the evolution of this circulation; to determine the impact of changes in domination in the region. Research hypotheses:
The different phases of increase in monetary production, as highlighted by numismatic studies, imply different stocks of metals. It could have come from Iberian mines, as archaeology has partially demonstrated for the Umayyad period, or from deposits outside the Peninsula, even outside al-Andalus. Metal of the same geographical origin could be used in several mints, and perhaps sub-Saharan gold was minted just as well in the Umayyad workshop at SiÇ§ilmÄsa as in CÃ³rdoba or in the Palatine city of MadÄ«nat al-ZahrÄ. The notable changes in the supply of coinage are the result of and reflect the contacts and influences in the western Mediterranean basin. The exploitation of silver mines in North Africa could have been a source of supply, particularly for the Iberian Peninsula, depending on the areas controlled by the various powers. Political developments and expansions in the Islamic states of the West may have influenced the circulation of precious metals. Umayyad control of SiÇ§ilmÄsa, and above all, the Berber conquests of the 12th-13th centuries probably led to the arrival of sub-Saharan gold in al-Andalus, where dinars of renowned quality were minted. The ALMACIR project proposes a multidisciplinary approach to achieve its objectives. Benefiting from a dense historiography on the subject, the project will be based on the most recent archaeological data on the Saharan zones, on a large-scale numismatic study, considering for the first time the coinage of all the Muslim states of the West between the 8th and 13th centuries, and on archaeometric data, which it proposes to develop to an extent never before envisaged for this coinage.
summary: What were the circulation networks for precious metals used in coinage in the Islamic West, from the Arab conquests to the Berber dynasties (8th-13th centuries)? Where did the gold and silver minted by the various States of the Islamic West come from? To what extent did political changes in the Maghreb and al-Andalus influence the circulation of precious metals?
title: Project

content:
Quels Ã©taient les rÃ©seaux de circulation des mÃ©taux prÃ©cieux utilisÃ©s dans la monnaie en Occident musulman, depuis les conquÃªtes arabes jusquâ€™aux dynasties berbÃ¨res (VIIIáµ‰â€“XIIIáµ‰ siÃ¨cles) ? Dâ€™oÃ¹ provenaient lâ€™or et lâ€™argent monnayÃ©s par les diffÃ©rents Ã‰tats de lâ€™Occident musulman ? Dans quelle mesure les changements politiques au Maghreb et en al-Andalus ont-ils influencÃ© la circulation des mÃ©taux prÃ©cieux ?
Le projet ALMACIR se concentre sur la partie occidentale du DÄr al-IslÄm, entre les conquÃªtes arabes du MaÄ¡rib al-AqsÄ et dâ€™al-Andalus au tournant des VIIáµ‰â€“VIIIáµ‰ siÃ¨cles, et la chute des Almohades en 668/1269. Sur la base du tÃ©moignage des sources Ã©crites, lâ€™historiographie traditionnelle et rÃ©cente a dÃ©montrÃ© lâ€™importance de lâ€™or subsaharien, les routes de sa circulation transitant par SiÇ§ilmÄsa, ainsi que la richesse dâ€™autres villes sahariennes situÃ©es au carrefour des routes du sel et de lâ€™or, telles quâ€™AwdaÄ¡ust (dans lâ€™actuelle Mauritanie). Les sources Ã©crites Ã©clairent Ã©galement lâ€™exploitation des mÃ©taux prÃ©cieux au Maghreb. Plus rÃ©cemment, les Ã©tudes archÃ©ologiques en Afrique du Nord, en particulier dans la rÃ©gion de SiÇ§ilmÄsa, ont apportÃ© une nouvelle dimension Ã  ces recherches. Si la circulation des mÃ©taux prÃ©cieux sâ€™est surtout concentrÃ©e sur lâ€™or, celle de lâ€™argent mÃ©rite dâ€™Ãªtre mise en valeur, notamment son Ã©ventuel mouvement vers la pÃ©ninsule IbÃ©rique depuis lâ€™Afrique du Nord, oÃ¹ se trouvaient des mines rÃ©putÃ©es, comme celles de lâ€™Atlas marocain dont la richesse fut soulignÃ©e par le gÃ©ographe du IXáµ‰ siÃ¨cle Ibn á¸ªudÄá¸bih. La rÃ©gion fut soumise Ã  diffÃ©rentes autoritÃ©s : le MaÄ¡rib al-AqsÄ se trouva progressivement liÃ© Ã  al-Andalus, avec lâ€™expansion du califat omeyyade de Cordoue au sud du dÃ©troit de Gibraltar jusquâ€™au contrÃ´le de SiÇ§ilmÄsa (366/976), puis avec les conquÃªtes et le retrait des Almoravides et des Almohades aux XIIáµ‰ et XIIIáµ‰ siÃ¨cles. Le projet repose sur un examen de la circulation de lâ€™or et de lâ€™argent dans ces contextes politiques variÃ©s, sous un nouveau jour : celui des caractÃ©ristiques de composition chimique des monnaies.
Objectifs principaux :
Ã©valuer la circulation de ces mÃ©taux sur une large chronologie entre lâ€™Afrique subsaharienne, le MaÄ¡rib al-AqsÄ et al-Andalus ; quantifier lâ€™Ã©volution de cette circulation ; dÃ©terminer lâ€™impact des changements de domination dans la rÃ©gion. HypothÃ¨ses de recherche :
Les diffÃ©rentes phases dâ€™accroissement de la production monÃ©taire, mises en Ã©vidence par les Ã©tudes numismatiques, impliquent des stocks de mÃ©taux variÃ©s. Ceux-ci pouvaient provenir des mines ibÃ©riques, comme lâ€™archÃ©ologie lâ€™a partiellement dÃ©montrÃ© pour la pÃ©riode omeyyade, ou de gisements extÃ©rieurs Ã  la pÃ©ninsule, voire en dehors dâ€™al-Andalus. Un mÃ©tal dâ€™une mÃªme origine gÃ©ographique pouvait Ãªtre utilisÃ© dans plusieurs ateliers monÃ©taires, et peut-Ãªtre lâ€™or subsaharien Ã©tait-il frappÃ© aussi bien dans lâ€™atelier omeyyade de SiÇ§ilmÄsa quâ€™Ã  Cordoue ou dans la citÃ© palatine de MadÄ«nat al-ZahrÄ. Les changements notables dans lâ€™approvisionnement monÃ©taire rÃ©sultent et reflÃ¨tent les contacts et influences dans le bassin occidental de la MÃ©diterranÃ©e. Lâ€™exploitation des mines dâ€™argent en Afrique du Nord a pu constituer une source dâ€™approvisionnement, notamment pour la pÃ©ninsule IbÃ©rique, selon les zones contrÃ´lÃ©es par les diffÃ©rents pouvoirs. Les Ã©volutions et expansions politiques des Ã‰tats islamiques de lâ€™Occident ont pu influencer la circulation des mÃ©taux prÃ©cieux. Le contrÃ´le omeyyade de SiÇ§ilmÄsa, et surtout les conquÃªtes berbÃ¨res des XIIáµ‰â€“XIIIáµ‰ siÃ¨cles, ont probablement entraÃ®nÃ© lâ€™arrivÃ©e de lâ€™or subsaharien en al-Andalus, oÃ¹ furent frappÃ©s des dinars de qualitÃ© renommÃ©e. Le projet ALMACIR propose une approche pluridisciplinaire pour atteindre ses objectifs. BÃ©nÃ©ficiant dâ€™une historiographie dense sur le sujet, il sâ€™appuiera sur les donnÃ©es archÃ©ologiques les plus rÃ©centes concernant les zones sahariennes, sur une Ã©tude numismatique Ã  grande Ã©chelle â€” prenant en compte pour la premiÃ¨re fois la production monÃ©taire de lâ€™ensemble des Ã‰tats musulmans dâ€™Occident entre les VIIIáµ‰ et XIIIáµ‰ siÃ¨cles â€” et sur des donnÃ©es archÃ©omÃ©triques, quâ€™il se propose de dÃ©velopper dans une ampleur jamais envisagÃ©e jusquâ€™Ã  prÃ©sent pour cette monÃ©tisation.
summary: Quels Ã©taient les rÃ©seaux de circulation des mÃ©taux prÃ©cieux utilisÃ©s dans la monnaie en Occident musulman, depuis les conquÃªtes arabes jusquâ€™aux dynasties berbÃ¨res (VIIIáµ‰â€“XIIIáµ‰ siÃ¨cles) ? Dâ€™oÃ¹ provenaient lâ€™or et lâ€™argent monnayÃ©s par les diffÃ©rents Ã‰tats de lâ€™Occident musulman ? Dans quelle mesure les changements politiques au Maghreb et en al-Andalus ont-ils influencÃ© la circulation des mÃ©taux prÃ©cieux ?
title: Projet Scientifique

content:
AL-Andalus â€“ MAghreb. CIRculation of gold and silver for coinage in the Medieval Islamic West (8th-13th centuries)
The circulation of gold from sub-Saharan Africa to the shores of the Mediterranean has received particular attention from medievalists historians. Written sources, in particular the texts of Arab geographers, bear witness to the wealth of regions from which the gold used in Arabic coinage was from. However, it is difficult to estimate the extent of this use. Similarly, while the exploitation of silver mines has been documented in the Maghreb, the use of this production in the coinage of the Islamic West has few been measured. While the circulation of precious metals towards al-Andalus has essentially been studied on the basis of evidence relating to gold, it seems essential to include silver in order to understand the dynamics of the circulation of precious metals in the western Mediterranean basin. The ALMACIR project aims to establish a reference system for the composition of gold and silver coins alloys from the medieval Islamic West, using laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS). Once the more than 700 dinars and dirhams submitted for analysis have been catalogued and entered into a database, the results will highlight the levels of trace elements, present as impurities in the ores and possible indicators of the origin of the metals. The objectives will be to assess the circulation of gold and silver and its evolution according to the changes in mint states, between the Arabic conquests in the West at the turn of the 7th-8th centuries and the fall of the Almohad dynasty in 1269. The study should thus shed light on trans-Saharan trade and metal production in West and North Africa, and renew the current vision of trans-Saharan trade and circulation networks between the MaÄ¡rib al-AqsÄ and al-Andalus.

AL-Andalus â€“ MAghreb. CIRculation of gold and silver for coinage in the Medieval Islamic West (8th-13th centuries)

The circulation of gold from sub-Saharan Africa to the shores of the Mediterranean has received particular attention from medievalists historians. Written sources, in particular the texts of Arab geographers, bear witness to the wealth of regions from which the gold used in Arabic coinage was from. However, it is difficult to estimate the extent of this use. Similarly, while the exploitation of silver mines has been documented in the Maghreb, the use of this production in the coinage of the Islamic West has few been measured. While the circulation of precious metals towards al-Andalus has essentially been studied on the basis of evidence relating to gold, it seems essential to include silver in order to understand the dynamics of the circulation of precious metals in the western Mediterranean basin. The ALMACIR project aims to establish a reference system for the composition of gold and silver coins alloys from the medieval Islamic West, using laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS). Once the more than 700 dinars and dirhams submitted for analysis have been catalogued and entered into a database, the results will highlight the levels of trace elements, present as impurities in the ores and possible indicators of the origin of the metals. The objectives will be to assess the circulation of gold and silver and its evolution according to the changes in mint states, between the Arabic conquests in the West at the turn of the 7th-8th centuries and the fall of the Almohad dynasty in 1269. The study should thus shed light on trans-Saharan trade and metal production in West and North Africa, and renew the current vision of trans-Saharan trade and circulation networks between the MaÄ¡rib al-AqsÄ and al-Andalus.
title: Presentation

content:
Well-thought-through product announcements will help increase feature awareness and engage users with new functionality. Just like sharing your public roadmap, it’s also a great way to let potential customers see that you’re constantly improving.
Further reading Read How to announce product updates and features
summary: You can use blog posts for announcing product updates and features.
title: Example Post

content:
Reference pages are ideal for outlining how things work in terse and clear terms. Less concerned with telling a story or addressing a specific use case, they should give a comprehensive outline of what your documenting.
Further reading Read about reference in the DiÃ¡taxis framework
